body_html:
By cmake output I mean the two-column list that the cmake command outputs before finishing. If you used setup.py or conda-build then some other script called cmake for you, but you can still find the output by searching for the word "Summary". EDIT: Actually after reading your post more carefully, your cmake command was failing before it printed out the list I'm looking for.

If you run "git submodule update --init --recursive" in the Pytorch root directory then it will clone all of those for you. Some of our build system may be hardcoded to look in these locations (in pytorch/third_party/). If you want to use another location for these (why do you want to do this?) then you can maybe put symlinks pointing to your locations e.g. "ln -s path/to/nnpack pytorch/third_party/nnpack"

body:
By cmake output I mean the two-column list that the cmake command outputs before finishing. If you used setup.py or conda-build then some other script called cmake for you, but you can still find the output by searching for the word "Summary". EDIT: Actually after reading your post more carefully, your cmake command was failing before it printed out the list I'm looking for.

If you run "git submodule update --init --recursive" in the Pytorch root directory then it will clone all of those for you. Some of our build system may be hardcoded to look in these locations (in pytorch/third_party/). If you want to use another location for these (why do you want to do this?) then you can maybe put symlinks pointing to your locations e.g. "ln -s path/to/nnpack pytorch/third_party/nnpack"
